TypeSignature.Value: .class public sequential ansi serializable sealed beforefieldinit RectangleF extends System.ValueType

Docs.summary: Stores a set of four floating-point numbers that represent the location and size of a rectangle. For more advanced region functions, use a object.

remarks.format: ## Remarks A rectangle is defined by its width, height, and upper-left corner.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype System.Drawing.PointF location, valuetype System.Drawing.SizeF size) cil managed

Docs.param: A that represents the upper-left corner of the rectangular region.
A that represents the width and height of the rectangular region.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified location and size.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF.op_Implicit%2A>, RectangleF, and <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF.op_Equality%2A> members. This example is designed for use with a Windows Form. Paste this code into a form and call the `ConvertRectangleToRectangleF` method when handling the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.
[!code-cs[System.Drawing.RectanglesAndPoints#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/5d8998f0-9d41-440a-a9e3-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.RectanglesAndPoints#6](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/5d8998f0-9d41-440a-a9e3-_1.cpp)] [!code-vb[System.Drawing.RectanglesAndPoints#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/5d8998f0-9d41-440a-a9e3-_1.vb)]

## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to use the RectangleF, <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle.Round%2A> and <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle.Truncate%2A> members. This example is designed for use with a Windows Form. Paste this code into a form and call the `RoundingAndTruncatingRectangles` method when handling the form's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint> event, passing `e` as <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Inflate(valuetype System.Drawing.SizeF size) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount to inflate this rectangle.
Docs.summary: Enlarges this by the specified amount.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method enlarges this rectangle, not a copy of it. The rectangle is enlarged in both directions along an axis. For example, if a 50 by 50 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resultant rectangle will be 150 units long (the original 50, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center.
## Examples This example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs> e, an OnPaint event object. The code creates a <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> and draws it to the screen in black. Notice that it has to be converted to a <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle> for drawing purposes. Then the code enlarges the <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF>, again converts it to a <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle>, and draws it to the screen in red. Notice that the original (black) rectangle is expanded in both directions along the x-axis by 100 points.
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.drawing.rectang_5_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.drawing.rectang_5_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#1](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/m-system.drawing.rectang_5_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public void Inflate (float x, float y);
.method public hidebysig instance void Inflate(float32 x, float32 y) cil managed

Docs.param: The amount to inflate this structure horizontally.
The amount to inflate this structure vertically.
Docs.summary: Enlarges this structure by the specified amount.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This method enlarges this rectangle, not a copy of it. The rectangle is enlarged in both directions along an axis. For example, if a 50 by 50 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resultant rectangle will be 150 units long (the original 50, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center.
If either `x` or `y` is negative, the <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> is deflated in the corresponding direction.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.RectangleF Inflate (System.Drawing.RectangleF rect, float x, float y);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF Inflate(valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF rect, float32 x, float32 y) cil managed

Docs.param: The to be copied. This rectangle is not modified.
The amount to enlarge the copy of the rectangle horizontally.
The amount to enlarge the copy of the rectangle vertically.
Docs.summary: Creates and returns an enlarged copy of the specified structure. The copy is enlarged by the specified amount and the original rectangle remains unmodified.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This method makes a copy of `rect`, enlarges the copy, and then returns the enlarged copy. The rectangle is enlarged in both directions along an axis. For example, if a 50 by 50 rectangle is inflated by 50 in the x-axis, the resultant rectangle will be 150 units long (the original 50, the 50 in the minus direction, and the 50 in the plus direction) maintaining the rectangle's geometric center.

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.RectangleF Intersect (System.Drawing.RectangleF a, System.Drawing.RectangleF b);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF Intersect(valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF a, valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF b) cil managed

Docs.param: A rectangle to intersect.
A rectangle to intersect.
Docs.summary: Returns a structure that represents the intersection of two rectangles. If there is no intersection, and empty is returned.
Docs.returns: A third structure the size of which represents the overlapped area of the two specified rectangles.

remarks.format:
## Examples This example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs>`e`, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code creates two <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> objects and draws them to the screen in black and red. Notice that they have to be converted to <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle> objects for drawing purposes. Then the code creates a third <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> using the <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF.Intersect%2A> method, converts it to a <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle>, and draws it to the screen in blue. Notice the third (blue) rectangle is the area of overlap of the other two rectangles:
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/47bd303e-f7ea-48d0-ae6d-_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/47bd303e-f7ea-48d0-ae6d-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#2](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/47bd303e-f7ea-48d0-ae6d-_1.cpp)]

MemberSignature.Value: public static System.Drawing.RectangleF Union (System.Drawing.RectangleF a, System.Drawing.RectangleF b);
.method public static hidebysig valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF Union(valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF a, valuetype System.Drawing.RectangleF b) cil managed

Docs.param: A rectangle to union.
A rectangle to union.
Docs.summary: Creates the smallest possible third rectangle that can contain both of two rectangles that form a union.
Docs.returns: A third structure that contains both of the two rectangles that form the union.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When one of the two rectangles is empty, meaning all of its values are zero, the <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle.Union%2A> method returns a rectangle with a starting point of (0, 0), and the height and width of the non-empty rectangle. For example, if you have two rectangles A = (0, 0; 0, 0) and B = (1, 1; 2, 2), then the union of A and B is (0, 0; 2, 2).
## Examples This example is designed for use with Windows Forms, and it requires <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs> e, an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.OnPaint%2A> event object. The code creates two <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> s and draws them to the screen in black and red. Notice that they have to be converted to <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle> s for drawing purposes. Then the code creates a third <xref:System.Drawing.RectangleF> using the Union method, converts it to a <xref:System.Drawing.Rectangle>, and draws it to the screen in blue. Notice the third (blue) rectangle is the smallest possible rectangle that can contain both of the other two rectangles:
[!code-vb[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/2f1239b4-8abf-4ed8-9c26-_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/2f1239b4-8abf-4ed8-9c26-_1.cs)] [!code-cpp[System.Drawing.ClassicRectangleFExamples#3](~/add/codesnippet/cpp/2f1239b4-8abf-4ed8-9c26-_1.cpp)]
